list.name: The Core
description: Written in JavaScript

The CORE was written for the yearly code-golfing competition js13kgames, running from August 13 2018 to September 13 2018. The goal of this competition is to submit a full game made within a month, with all assets, libraries, etc coming in at under 13Kb compressed and able to run off-line. The theme of this competition was "offline".

You are one of many workers trapped in a factory and forced to work on THE CORE, a sinister mind control machine. The first version of THE CORE currently has everyone in the factory (workers, guards, managers) under it's control. The second version will enslave the world! Find the four keys, and use the on THE CORE to take it offline for good!
For a fun surprise, make sure to speak to a guard after you have taken the machine offline :)

list.name: Defend The Castle
list.shortText: A twist on the classic tower defense genre!
description: Written in JavaScript
Defend the Castle is a fast-paced arcade-style video game. The engine and game were written from scratch, and it runs right in your browser (best on Firefox and Google Chrome).

I wanted to create this game from scratch, to better understand how game engines work under the hood. The biggest challenge surfaced when I discovered that the tutorial I was following didn't actually bring the game to a basic completion. The series had left me with a solid foundation, no doubt, consisting of a tile map loader, a game camera, keyboard input and a hero to control, some basic collision detection, and some entity handling. The rest was up to me. Did I really want to stick this through, knowing it would be extremely challenging? In the end, I had to fully immerse myself in to this code base, and really learn how it worked in order to achieve the results that I desired. It was a wonderful learning experience.

list.name: Golden Beak Golf
description: Written in Pico-8 fantasy console.
Golden Beak Golf v1.0 was written during Ludum Dare 41 game jam taking place April 20th to April 23rd, 2018. The theme was "Combine two incompatible genres".
Golden Beak Golf v1.1 was an update to smooth out a couple of things:
• Main menu redesign.
• Graphics tweaks, and more animated sprites in background.
• Press Z to replay working properly.

list.name: Me, Myself, and i
list.shortText: "What is this strange fog and smell of decay?"
description: Written in JavaScript.
This game was written for the JS13kgames 2017 game jam, where you have a month to write a game from scratch with a complete project size limitation of 13kb.
The theme for js13kgames 2017 was "Lost".

Every time you start the game, you play as one in a series of hundreds of clones. These clones are dropped in to this maze of death and darkness as a test, with only the survivors having a chance to see the light of day again.

As you explore this maze, you will encounter other clones who couldn't make it out alive. They are rotten, and have been driven mad by the voice inside their head. Hopefully that same voice doesn't reach out to infect you...

list.name: Waves '87: Business Cruizin'
list.shortText: Take a cruise. No seriously, TAKE A CRUISE.
description: Written in Python with the Ren'Py graphic novel engine.
This game was made during Global Game Jam 2017, which took place over 48 hour weekend period in January of 2017.
All sounds effects and music were recorded during Global Game Jam 2017
Kawa is your typical business man. Loathed by his peers and about to be fired from his job, a chance encounter with pirates may just turn his life around...
Builds of the game are available below for Linux, Mac, and PC.

list.name: ToDon't List Client
list.shortText: A communal collection of bad habits.
description: Written in JavaScript with the REACT Framework
This is the front-end of the ToDont' List app. I wanted to branch out and use a framework, like REACT, that I was a little less familiar with.
During this project I learned a bit more about REACTs lifecycle hooks, and how to deploy a REACT app to Github Pages as well.

list.name: ToDon't List API
list.shortText: The back-end of the ToDon't List app.
description: Written using NodeJS, the MongoDB, Express, and mLab the database-as-a-service for MongoDB
As with the front-end, I wanted to branch out and work with some technologies that I was less familiar with, like the MERN stack.
During this project I learned about using a database-as-a-service system like mLab, and how to deploy a node app to Heroku as well.

list.name: Battle Bots
list.shortText: Local two player battle to the robot death!
description: Written in HTML5, CSS, and JavaScript using Grunt, Browserify, and jQuery.
Each player chooses one of six classes (Johnny5, Wall-E, R2D2, R2BRO2, Bender, Baymax).
This project was exercise in prototypal inheritance.

list.name: Bangazon CLI
description: Written in Python, with unit tests and SQL.

This was a group project. The CLI tool is a command line interface that allows the creation and storage of customer accounts, payment options, and orders, the storage and adding of products from the database in to the active order, the completion of an order after adding products and selecting a payment option, and a display of the current product popularity rankings by revenue generated.

This project allowed me to really dig in to SQL and Python. My contributions to this project include the ERD, the payment option class and unit tests, the refactoring of said class and tests, and the SQL database interactions for order and payment option models.

list.name: Future Unlimited
list.shortText: "Throwback rarely feels this genuine, a real accomplishment amongst so much nostalgia." - Adam Kivel, consequenceofsound.net
description: During my time with Future Unlimited, I toured the country, wrote and recorded songs with the band, and played bass guitar (and sometimes keyboards).
We played festivals such as Bonaroo, Austin City Limits, Art Basel, and SXSW.
We have a music video directed by Shia LaBeouf for the single, "Haunted Love"
We released two EPs and multiple singles.

list.shortText: "STA has potential to remind us 20-somethings why we decided to like music in the first place." - Jennifer R. Vertullo, epitaph.com
